DOC.brief_title: Incidence Male Pudendal Artery Stenosis Suboptimal Erections Study
DOC.detailed_description: Vascular insufficiency commonly cite cause Erectile Dysfunction ( ED ) common treatment ED target aspect penile vasculature . Initial pharmacotherapy typically focus penile microvasculature ; however , surgical revascularization also use treat ED cause lesion internal iliac artery ( IIA ) and/or internal pudendal artery ( IPA ) penile artery . Anatomically , surgical revascularization connects inferior epigastric artery dorsal artery penis combination dorsal artery vein penis . The pudendal artery deep artery penis usually target surgical bypass . Recent advance percutaneous revascularization spark interest penile revascularization treat ED . However , new percutaneous treatment modality evolve , several important clinical question remain unanswered . Important among normal angiographic anatomy erectile related artery ( ERA ) , angiographic finding correlate symptom ED ? Also , many men could possible benefit percutaneous revascularization ? The normal IPA anatomy contrast angiography well defined study correlate IPA finding erectile function . While study do population men suspect vasculogenic chronic ED , study establish normal angiographic anatomy IPA evaluate prevalence angiographic IPA occlusive disease . Therefore , angiographic prevalence study assist determine population men could potentially benefit percutaneous treatment atherosclerotic IPA lesion .
DOC.criteria: Subject must undergo coronary peripheral angiography suspect known coronary peripheral atherosclerotic disease Subject must male ≥ 35 ≤ 70 year old Subject must provide write informed consent studyrelated procedure perform Subject must agree comply study procedure followup entire length study Subject unable safely attempt sexual intercourse secondary severe cardiac disease health condition Subject life expectancy < 12 month Subject 's serum creatinine > 2.5 mg/dl Subject know aortoiliac occlusive disease , previous AAA endograft procedure open surgical procedure Subject history prostatic carcinoma require surgery ( i.e. , prostatectomy ) , pelvic radiation , hormonal/chemotherapy Subject history myocardial infarction , stroke , lifethreatening arrhythmia , unstable angina require hospitalization within 3 month ( 90 day ) prior enrollment Subject exposure PDE5 inhibitor ( per subject 's concomitant medication list ) within 72 hour prior schedule baseline angiography Subject history renal transplantation Subject penile implant Subject become unstable received maximum radiation dose , increased procedure time , and/or maximum contrast dose ( Investigator 's opinion ) primary angiographic procedure would compromise safety subject proceed enrollment IMPASSE study
